definitions.example: The reel automatically took up the slack.

definitions.definition: To begin doing (an activity) on a regular basis.
definitions.example: I wish to take up mathematics.
Let's take this up with the manager.

definitions.definition: To occupy; to consume (space or time).
definitions.example: All my time is taken up with looking after the kids.
If we take up the sleeves a bit, that shirt will look much better on you.

definitions.definition: To remove the surface or bed of a road.
(with 'on') To accept (a proposal, offer, request, etc.) from.
definitions.example: Shall we take them up on their offer to help us move?
let's take up where we left off

definitions.definition: To implement, to employ, to put into use.
The act of taking something up, by tightening, absorption, or reeling in.
(machinery) That which takes up or tightens; specifically, a device in a sewing machine or loom for drawing up the slack thread as the needle rises, in completing a stitch.
Acceptance (of a proposal, offer, request, etc.).
definitions.example: the take-up of benefits by the unemployed
